query: How many moons does jupyter have?

results.title: How Many Moons Does Jupiter Have? | Names, Locations & Number
results.content: Though Jupiter has 79 moons, 63 of them are less than 10 km / 6.2 mi in diameter. Jupiter's regular moons consist of the Galilean moons and an inner group of 4 small moons with diameters less than 200 km / 124 mi, and orbits with radii less than 200,000 km / 124,274 mi. All of these moons have orbital inclinations of less than half a degree.

results.title: Moons of Jupiter - Wikipedia
results.content: There are 95 moons of Jupiter with confirmed orbits as of 5 February 2024. [1] [note 1] This number does not include a number of meter-sized moonlets thought to be shed from the inner moons, nor hundreds of possible kilometer-sized outer irregular moons that were only briefly captured by telescopes. [4] All together, Jupiter's moons form a ...

results.title: Jupiter Moons - Science@NASA
results.content: Jupiter has 95 moons that have been officially recognized by the International Astronomical Union. But the number doesn't capture the complexity of the Jovian system of moons, rings and asteroids. The giant planet has thousands of small objects in its orbit. Scientists are getting so good at spotting tiny moons orbiting distant, giant planets ...

results.title: All Jupiter Moons - Science@NASA
results.content: Quick Facts. Galileo Galilei spotted the first Jupiter moons in 1610 with a new invention called a telescope. German astronomer Simon Marius found Jupiter's moons about the same time as Galileo, but Galileo was first to report the moons and is credited with their discovery. Modern astronomer Scott S. Sheppard has discovered the most moons of ...

results.title: Moons of Jupiter | Table, Names, Sizes, & List | Britannica
results.content: Jupiter is the largest planet in the solar system and has, as of 2023, 95 known moons. The four largest moons of Jupiter—Io, Callisto, Ganymede, and Europa—were the first objects in the solar system discovered with a telescope. Galileo discovered them in 1610, and they are now called the Galilean satellites.

"[\"{\\\"url\\\": \\\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moons_of_Jupiter\\\", \\\"content\\\": \\\"In a February 2023 interview with NPR, Sheppard noted that he and his team are currently tracking even more moons of Jupiter, which should place Jupiter's moon count over 100 once confirmed over the next two years.[41]\\\\nMany more irregular moons of Jupiter will inevitably be discovered in the future, especially after the beginning of deep sky surveys by the upcoming Vera C. Rubin Observatory and Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope in the mid-2020s.[42][43] The Rubin Observatory's 8.4-meter (28\\\\u00a0ft) aperture telescope and 3.5\\\\u00a0square-degree field of view will probe Jupiter's irregular moons down to diameters of 1\\\\u00a0km (0.6\\\\u00a0mi)[10]:\\\\u200a265\\\\u200a at apparent magnitudes of 24.5, with the potential of increasing the known population by up to tenfold.[42]:\\\\u200a292\\\\u200a Likewise, the Roman Space Telescope's 2.4-meter (7.9\\\\u00a0ft) aperture and 0.28\\\\u00a0square-degree field of view will probe Jupiter's irregular moons down to diameters of 0.3\\\\u00a0km (0.2\\\\u00a0mi) at magnitude 27.7, with the potential of discovering approximately 1,000 Jovian moons above this size.[43]:\\\\u200a24\\\\u200a Discovering these many irregular satellites will help reveal their population's size distribution and collisional histories, which will place further constraints to how the Solar System formed.[43]:\\\\u200a24\\\\u201325\\\\nDiscovery of outer planet moons\\\\nNaming[edit]\\\\nThe Galilean moons of Jupiter (Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto) were named by Simon Marius soon after their discovery in 1610.[44] No additional moons were discovered until two decades later, with the fortuitous discovery of Callirrhoe by the Spacewatch survey in October 1999.[25] During the 1990s, photographic plates phased out as digital charge-coupled device (CCD) cameras began emerging in telescopes on Earth, allowing for wide-field surveys of the sky at unprecedented sensitivities and ushering in a wave of new moon discoveries.[26] Scott Sheppard, then a graduate student of David Jewitt, demonstrated this extended capability of CCD cameras in a survey conducted with the Mauna Kea Observatory's 2.2-meter (88\\\\u00a0in) UH88 telescope in November 2000, discovering eleven new irregular moons of Jupiter including the previously lost Themisto with the aid of automated computer algorithms.[27]\\\\nFrom 2001 onward, Sheppard and Jewitt alongside other collaborators continued surveying for Jovian irregular moons with the 3.6-meter (12\\\\u00a0ft) Canada-France-Hawaii Telescope (CFHT), discovering an additional eleven in December 2001, one in October 2002, and nineteen in February 2003.[27][1] The other moons were simply labeled by their Roman numeral (e.g. Jupiter IX) in the majority of astronomical literature until the 1970s.[50] Several different suggestions were made for names of Jupiter's outer satellites, but none were universally accepted until 1975 when the International Astronomical Union's (IAU) Task Group for Outer Solar System Nomenclature granted names to satellites V\\\\u2013XIII,[51] and provided for a formal naming process for future satellites still to be discovered.[51] The practice was to name newly discovered moons of Jupiter after lovers and favorites of the god Jupiter (Zeus) and, since 2004, also after their descendants.[48] All of Jupiter's satellites from XXXIV (Euporie) onward are named after descendants of Jupiter or Zeus,[48] except LIII (Dia), named after a lover of Jupiter. Names ending with \\\\\\\"a\\\\\\\" or \\\\\\\"o\\\\\\\" are used for prograde irregular satellites (the latter for highly inclined satellites), and names ending with \\\\\\\"e\\\\\\\" are used for retrograde irregulars.[26] With the discovery of smaller, kilometre-sized moons around Jupiter, the IAU has established an additional convention to limit the naming of small moons with absolute magnitudes greater than 18 or diameters smaller than 1\\\\u00a0km (0.6\\\\u00a0mi).[52] Some of the most recently confirmed moons have not received names.[4]\\\\nSome asteroids share the same names as moons of Jupiter: 9 Metis, 38 Leda, 52 Europa, 85 Io, 113 Amalthea, 239 Adrastea. The first were Pioneer\\\\u00a010 in 1973, and Pioneer\\\\u00a011 a year later, taking low-resolution images of the four Galilean moons and returning data on their atmospheres and radiation belts.[72] The Voyager\\\\u00a01 and Voyager\\\\u00a02 probes visited Jupiter in 1979, discovering the volcanic activity on\\\\u00a0Io and the presence of water ice on the surface of Europa.\\\"}\", \"{\\\"url\\\": \\\"https://nineplanets.org/questions/how-many-moons-does-jupiter-have/\\\", \\\"content\\\": \\\"It is also the fourth-largest moon in the Solar System, yet it has the highest density and the least amount of water molecules of any known celestial object in the Solar System.\\\\n Many missions are planned for Jupiter in the following years, and many of them target the four biggest moons of Jupiter, the Galilean Moons. Jupiter\\\\u2019s regular moons consist of the Galilean moons and an inner group of 4 small moons with diameters less than 200 km / 124 mi, and orbits with radii less than 200,000 km / 124,274 mi.\\\\n It has the lowest density of Jupiter\\\\u2019s moons, and its surface appears to be the oldest and most heavily cratered in the Solar System. The Galilean Moons\\\\nIo\\\\nIo is the innermost and third-largest of the four Galilean moons.\\\"}\", \"{\\\"url\\\": \\\"https://science.nasa.gov/jupiter/moons/all-jupiter-moons/\\\", \\\"content\\\": \\\"All Moons of Jupiter Most of Jupiter's swarms of smaller moons orbit much farther out than the Galilean satellites. Of these distant moons, the larger ones may be captured asteroids. The smaller ones are likely fragments from massive collisions. Quick Facts\\\"}\", \"{\\\"url\\\": \\\"https://science.nasa.gov/jupiter/moons/\\\", \\\"content\\\": \\\"Discover More Topics From NASA\\\\nSun\\\\nPlanets\\\\nAsteroids, Comets & Meteors\\\\nKuiper Belt\\\\nThe National Aeronautics and Space Administration\\\\nNASA explores the unknown in air and space, innovates for the benefit of humanity, and inspires the world through discovery.\\\\n Location\\\\nJovian System\\\\nFirst Discoveries\\\\nJan. 7, 1610\\\\nMoon Count\\\\n95\\\\nNext mission\\\\nEuropa Clipper\\\\nFeatured Moons\\\\nJupiter's four largest moons were the first moons discovered beyond Earth. Here they are in order of size:\\\\nGanymede\\\\nGanymede is Jupiter's largest moon, and the largest moon in our solar system. Callisto\\\\nCallisto is Jupiter\\\\u2019s second largest moon and the third largest moon in our solar system.\\\\n Io\\\\nIo is Jupiter's third largest moon, and the most volcanically active world in our solar system.\\\\n\\\"}\", \"{\\\"url\\\": \\\"https://www.britannica.com/topic/moons-of-Jupiter-2236909\\\", \\\"content\\\": \\\"The four largest moons of Jupiter\\\\u2014Io, Callisto, Ganymede, and Europa\\\\u2014were the first objects in the solar system discovered with a telescope. Galileo discovered them in 1610, and they are now called the Galilean satellites. The fifth known Jovian moon, Amalthea, was also discovered by visual observation, by Edward Emerson Barnard in 1892.\\\"}\"]"
Based on the latest information available, Jupiter has over 100 moons.
